channel.title: NPR Topics: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Apprehension in Denmark ahead of talks about Greenland with Vance
item.description: Leaders from Denmark and Greenland will meet with top U.S. officials in Washington on Wednesday to try to find a way out of a crisis caused by President Trump repeated demands to annex Greenland.
item.content:encoded: Leaders from Denmark and Greenland will meet with top U.S. officials in Washington on Wednesday to try to find a way out of a crisis caused by President Trump repeated demands to annex Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Adrienne Murray

item.title: As Iran's protests continue, Israelis and Palestinians watch closely
item.description: There is broad support for the protests among Israeli officials, but Palestinians say they hope the Iranian regime stays in place and the protests die down soon.
item.content:encoded:
There is broad support for the protests among Israeli officials, but Palestinians say they hope the Iranian regime stays in place and the protests die down soon.

(Image credit: Vahid Salemi)
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: Minnesota sues over Trump's ICE enforcement. And, SCOTUS hears trans athlete cases
item.description: Minnesota officials sued the Trump administration over unconstitutional ICE conduct. And, SCOTUS hears two cases on whether states can bar transgender athletes from women's sports.
item.content:encoded:
Minnesota officials sued the Trump administration over unconstitutional ICE conduct. And, SCOTUS hears two cases on whether states can bar transgender athletes from women's sports.

(Image credit: John MacDougall)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Trump continues to threaten military action against Iran
item.description: Amid a deadly crackdown on protesters in Iran, President Trump continues to threaten military action against Tehran and warned countries that do business with Iran that he could impose a tariff.
item.content:encoded: Amid a deadly crackdown on protesters in Iran, President Trump continues to threaten military action against Tehran and warned countries that do business with Iran that he could impose a tariff.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Iran expert talks about the Trump administration's strategy with Iran
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Iran expert Karim Sadjadpour about the U.S. strategy toward Iran and why he believes Iran's regime could collapse.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Iran expert Karim Sadjadpour about the U.S. strategy toward Iran and why he believes Iran's regime could collapse.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: UN International Court of Justice to hear 1st genocide case in over a decade
item.description: The United Nations International Court of Justice is hearing a genocide case for the first time in more than a decade. The case is focused on the persecution of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.
item.content:encoded: The United Nations International Court of Justice is hearing a genocide case for the first time in more than a decade. The case is focused on the persecution of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: 'Fly, Wild Swans' is Jung Chang's painfully personal tribute to her mother
item.description: A historian of modern China, Jung Chang turns the lens back on herself in her newest book to understand how she sees the world and why she writes about China today.
item.content:encoded: A historian of modern China, Jung Chang turns the lens back on herself in her newest book to understand how she sees the world and why she writes about China today.
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: Markets and restaurants return to Gaza, but few can afford the expensive price tag
item.description: New eateries are popping up in Gaza after months of famine, but it's pricey and many people still rely on aid to survive.
item.content:encoded: New eateries are popping up in Gaza after months of famine, but it's pricey and many people still rely on aid to survive.
item.dc:creator: Aya Batrawy

item.title: People in Iran describe heavy security and some damage in first calls to outside world
item.description: Iranians made phone calls abroad for the first time in days Tuesday after authorities severed communications during a crackdown on nationwide protests that activists say killed at least 646 people.
item.content:encoded:
Iranians made phone calls abroad for the first time in days Tuesday after authorities severed communications during a crackdown on nationwide protests that activists say killed at least 646 people.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Elon Musk's X faces bans and investigations over nonconsensual bikini images
item.description: After the social media app's AI chatbot started generating sexualized images of women and children, two countries have blocked it and several more have launched investigations.
item.content:encoded:
After the social media app's AI chatbot started generating sexualized images of women and children, two countries have blocked it and several more have launched investigations.

(Image credit: Leon Neal)
item.dc:creator: Huo Jingnan
